title: Tai McIsaac
text:
Tai McIsaac (born 19 March 1975, in <a href="Brisbane">Brisbane</a>) is an Australian <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> football coach, and a former professional player. He is currently the head coach of the <a href="Perth%20Spirit">Perth Spirit</a> team in Australia's <a href="National%20Rugby%20Championship">National Rugby Championship</a>. McIsaac played as a hooker for the <a href="Western%20Force">Western Force</a> and <a href="Queensland%20Reds">Queensland Reds</a> in the <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> competition before retiring from playing in 2009.
Career.
Prior to rugby, McIsaac had been a National League <a href="water%20polo">water polo</a> player and represented Australian water polo in the under-21 team. Although he eventually specialised as a hooker, McIsaac started out in rugby at the age of 23, playing as a prop. He began his rugby career at Bond Pirates in the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20District%20Rugby%20Union">Gold Coast District Rugby Union</a>, later moving on to the <a href="Gold%20Coast%20Breakers">Gold Coast Breakers</a> in <a href="Queensland%20Premier%20Rugby">Queensland Premier Rugby</a>. McIsaac's first professional contract was with the <a href="Queensland%20Reds">Queensland Reds</a> in the Super 12 competition. He made his Super 12 debut in 2003 in a match against New Zealand team, the <a href="Crusaders%20%28rugby%29">Crusaders</a>. Also that year, McIsaac toured Japan with Australia A.
In 2005, he signed with the Western Force for their inaugural season in 2006. McIsaac made his debut for <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">the Wallabies</a> against <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> in 2006, and went on to claim 8 Test caps in that season. After four seasons at the Force, he retired from playing rugby in 2009.
McIsaac began his coaching career with <a href="Honda%20Heat">Honda Heat</a> in Japan for the 2009–10 season. McIsaac was head coach of the <a href="Toyota%20Industries%20Shuttles">Toyota Industries Shuttles</a> for several seasons until 2013–14. He then returned to Australia to take up an assistant coaching position at the <a href="Western%20Force">Western Force</a> in 2015. He was also appointed head coach of the <a href="Perth%20Spirit">Perth Spirit</a> for the 2015 season of the <a href="National%20Rugby%20Championship">National Rugby Championship</a>.
